holdings.text: A person who seizes cattle illegally, purporting to act under S. 10 of the Cattle Trespass Act, 1871, does not commit the offence of theft or robbery.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises the question whether a person who seizes cattle illegally, purporting to act under S. 10 of the Cattle Trespass Act, 1871, hereinafter the Act, commits the offence of theft or robbery or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of Cattle Trespass Act comprehensively regulate seizures and provide civil remedies under Chapter V; lacks dishonest intention under IPC s.378 as movement to pound is authorized by Act; no wrongful gain/loss.

holdings.text: By seizing the cattle purporting under s.10 of the Act, even illegally, the appellants did not commit the offence of theft.

anchor.surface_text: To determine the question raised, it is desirable to refer to the provisions of the Act... whether by so seizing the cattle the appellants committed the offence of theft.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dishonest intention absent per IPC ss.23,24,378; seizure and movement to pound per Act not dishonest; Chapter V remedies exclusive; precedents distinguished where no purported Act authority.

holdings.text: No right of private defence of property arose in favour of Shamnarain Singh and others as no offence (theft) was committed by the seizure.

anchor.surface_text: a right arises against the commission of an offence as defined in s. 40 I.P.C. i.e., an act which amounts to a thing made punishable by the Code. therefore no right of private defence of property arose in favour of Shamnarain Singh and others

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right of private defence under IPC ss.96-106 arises only against offence per s.40 IPC; illegal seizure not offence hence no right to use force to rescue cattle.

holdings.text: Rattan and others had right of private defence of their bodies against the armed prosecution party, justifying injuries and death caused.

anchor.surface_text: Even if Shamnarain Singhs party were not the aggressors and the attack was started by the party of Rattan, as appears to be the view of the High Court, that would not give any right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Armed rescue party created apprehension of death/grievous hurt; Sessions Judge view of aggression reasonable; injuries proportionate.

holdings.text: Members of prosecution party had no right of private defence of property to recover cattle by force as seizure not theft.

anchor.surface_text: To consider the question of law raised in this appeal, we accept the findings of the High Court to the effect that the plot in suit was in the possession of Shamnarain Singh

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in treating illegal seizure as theft/dacoity; no offence committed, remedy under Cattle Trespass Act ss.20-22 only.

holdings.text: Provisions of Chapter V of Cattle Trespass Act comprehensively deal with illegal seizures; no Penal Code offence.

anchor.surface_text: The Act does not make the illegal seizure of cattle punishable as an offence. The person seizing cattle illegally is made liable to pay compensation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature intended exclusive civil remedies ss.20-24; police aid for seizures; protects purported seizures to safeguard crops.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's view that Shamnarain Singh's party was aggressor reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge was inclined to the view that Shamnarain Singhs party was the aggressor. The view cannot be said to be unreasonable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances, injuries support; even if not, defence apprehension justified.

precedents.citation: K. N. Mehra v. The State of Rajasthan 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court had occasion to consider at length what commission of theft consists of, in K. N. Mehra v. The State of Rajasthan 1 . It said at p. 630 Commission of theft, therefore, consists in  1  moving a movable property of a person out of his possession without his consent,

precedents.case_name: K. N. Mehra v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: commission of theft consists in moving a movable property out of possession without consent with dishonest intention
precedents.cited_holding: Commission of theft, therefore, consists in 1 moving a movable property of a person out of his possession without his consent, 2 the moving being in order to the taking of the property with a dishonest intention.

anchor.surface_text: We may now briefly consider the cases referred to in support of the contention that illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft. These cases were not of the seizure and impounding of cattle in the purported exercise of the powers under s. 10 of the Act. They are Queen v. Preonath Banerjee 1  Wazuddi v. Rahimuddi 2  Abdul Khaliq v. Emperor   3   Paryag Rai v. Arju Mian 4  Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5 .

precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft

anchor.surface_text: Queen v. Preonath Banerjee 1  Wazuddi v. Rahimuddi 2  Abdul Khaliq v. Emperor   3   Paryag Rai v. Arju Mian 4  Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5 . In these cases seizure of cattle was not made even ostensibly on account of their causing damage to any land or crop. They were seized and taken away by persons in order to get their claims against the owners satisfied, or in order to cause them loss otherwise.

precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft

anchor.surface_text: Wazuddi v. Rahimuddi 2  Abdul Khaliq v. Emperor   3   Paryag Rai v. Arju Mian 4  Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5 . In these cases seizure of cattle was not made even ostensibly on account of their causing damage to any land or crop. They were seized and taken away by persons in order to get their claims against the owners satisfied,

precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Khaliq v. Emperor   3   Paryag Rai v. Arju Mian 4  Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5 . In these cases seizure of cattle was not made even ostensibly on account of their causing damage to any land or crop. They were seized and taken away by persons in order to get their claims against the owners satisfied, or in order to cause them loss otherwise. Such seizures of cattle, was rightly held to amount to theft.

precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft

precedents.citation: Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5

anchor.surface_text: Paryag Rai v. Arju Mian 4  Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo 5 . In these cases seizure of cattle was not made even ostensibly on account of their causing damage to any land or crop. They were seized and taken away by persons in order to get their claims against the owners satisfied, or in order to cause them loss otherwise. Such seizures of cattle, was rightly held to amount to theft.

precedents.case_name: Queen Empress v. Sri Churn Chungo
precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle amounts to theft

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand there are cases which held that no offence is committed by a person seizing cattle illegally. In Empress v. Ramjiawan 6  it was held that illegal seizure of cattle under the Act was not an offence of mischief under the Penal Code and, that the remedy of the owner of the cattle was to be found in the provisions of ss. 20, 21 and 22.

precedents.cited_proposition: illegal seizure of cattle under the Act was not an offence of mischief under the Penal Code; remedy in ss. 20-22
precedents.cited_holding: illegal seizure of cattle under the Act was not an offence of mischief under the Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: In Dayal v. Emperor 7  persons who had seized cattle from a pound and impounded them in retaliation of the action of the owners of the cattle in justifiably impounding their cattle a day earlier, were held not to have committed the offence of mischief under s. 425 I.P.C. inasmuch as driving the cattle to the pound did not in any way lead to the diminution in the utility or value of the cattle and not to have committed the offence of theft as no wrongful loss was caused to the owners of cattle even though they would have had to incur expenses in order to get them released.

precedents.cited_proposition: seizing cattle from pound in retaliation not mischief or theft; no wrongful loss caused
precedents.cited_holding: not committed offence of mischief or theft as no wrongful loss
